'''Dean Brody''' (born August 12, 1975) is a Canadian [[country music]] artist from British Columbia.<ref name="progress" /> He has won 16 [[Canadian Country Music Association#CCMA Awards|CCMA Awards]] and 2 [[JUNO Awards]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ccma.org/cgi/page.cgi/_article.html/News/Complete_List_of_2017_CCMA_Award_Winners|title=Complete List of 2017 CCMA Award Winners – Canadian Country Music Association|website=www.ccma.org|language=en|access-date=September 13, 2017|archive-date=November 24, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181124211554/https://www.ccma.org/cgi/page.cgi/_article.html/News/Complete_List_of_2017_CCMA_Award_Winners|url-status=dead}}</ref> 

Originally signed to [[Broken Bow Records]] in 2008, Brody made his debut later that year with the single "[[Brothers (Dean Brody song)|Brothers]]". This song, a Top 40 country hit in the US, was the first single from his [[Dean Brody (album)|self-titled debut album]], released in 2009 under the production of Matt Rovey. In 2010, Brody was signed to [[Open Road Recordings]] and released his second album, ''[[Trail in Life]]''. In 2012, he released his third album, ''[[Dirt (Dean Brody album)|Dirt]]'', earning the 2012 [[Canadian Country Music Association|CCMA]] Album of the Year award and a [[Juno Awards of 2013|2013 Juno]] nomination for [[Juno Award for Country Album of the Year|Country Album of the Year]]. Brody also won the 2012 and 2013 CCMA Male Artist of the Year award. Brody's fourth album, ''[[Crop Circles (album)|Crop Circles]]'', was released in 2013. Brody's fifth album, ''[[Gypsy Road (album)|Gypsy Road]]'', was released in 2015. Brody's sixth album, ''[[Beautiful Freakshow]]'', was released in 2016, and he subsequently earned the singer 3 Awards at the 2017 CCMA Awards show, including Fan's Choice, Songwriter of the Year and Top-Selling Canadian Single of the Year for "Bush Party".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://topcountry.ca/ccma-award-winners-2017/|title=CCMA Awards: Did Your Favourite Canadian Country Artist Win?!|date=September 1, 2017|work=Top Country Music {{!}} Country Music News, Charts, Playlists, Videos|access-date=September 12, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref> In 2020, Brody landed the record for the most played song ever in a single week at Canadian country radio with "[[Canadian Summer]]", which was included on his seventh album ''[[Boys (Dean Brody album)|Boys]]''.<ref name="record"/> He is the only Canadian country artist to have headlined the [[Budweiser Stage]] in [[Toronto, Ontario|Toronto]] for six consecutive years.<ref name="YGTWG">{{cite web|url=https://canadianbeats.ca/2022/10/04/dean-brody-shares-his-new-single-you-got-the-wrong-guy/|title=Dean Brody shares his new single, "You Got The Wrong Guy"|first=Nanci|last=Dagg|date=October 4, 2022|work=Canadian Beats Media}}</ref>

==Biography==
Dean Brody was born in [[Smithers, British Columbia]] and grew up in [[Jaffray, British Columbia]]. As a boy, Brody worked at a [[sawmill]], also playing guitar in his spare time. By 2004, he had moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]] to pursue his musical career. Although he found a songwriting contract, the expiration of his US work permit forced him to move back to Canada. Eventually, he returned to Nashville through the suggestion of producer [[Keith Stegall]], who helped him sign with [[Broken Bow Records]] in 2008.<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p1122694/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Dean Brody biography|last=Leggett|first=Steve|work=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=April 9, 2009}}</ref> Brody released his debut single, "Brothers", late that year. Shortly before its release, Brody was injured in a [[waterskiing]] accident on the [[Potomac River]] and had to undergo extensive reconstructive surgery.<ref name="southshorenow">{{Cite web |url=http://southshorenow.ca/archives/2011/091311/arts/index009.php |title=Dean Brody's 'trail in life' leads him to the South Shore |access-date=September 13, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323210746/http://southshorenow.ca/archives/2011/091311/arts/index009.php |archive-date=March 23, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref name="cmt">{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.ca/Artist/DeanBrody|title=Dean Brody biography|work=[[Country Music Television|CMT]] Canada|access-date=December 17, 2008|archive-date=November 21, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101121035045/http://cmt.ca/artist/deanbrody|url-status=dead}}</ref> Brody lived in [[Windsor, Nova Scotia]] and [[Chester, Nova Scotia]] from 2010 to 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://atlantic.ctvnews.ca/mobile/nova-scotia-has-some-country-twang-says-dean-brody-1.2554105|title= Nova Scotia has some country twang, says Dean Brody|work=[[CTV Television Network|CTV]] News Atlantic|publisher=[[Bell Media]]|first=Aly|last=Thomson|date=September 9, 2015|access-date=June 23, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://seaandbescene.com/2010/08/dean-brody-at-home-here-in-nova-scotia-cfa/|title=Dean Brody – At Home Here in Nova Scotia|work=Sea and be Scene.com|date=August 2010|access-date=June 23, 2020|archive-date=August 21, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160821070913/http://seaandbescene.com/2010/08/dean-brody-at-home-here-in-nova-scotia-cfa/|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.thechronicleherald.ca/lifestyles/dean-brodys-dirt-road-leads-back-to-nova-scotia-251306/|title=Dean Brody's Dirt Road leads back to Nova Scotia|work=[[The Chronicle Herald]]|publisher=SaltWire Network|first=Stephen|last=Cooke|date=October 18, 2018|access-date=June 23, 2020}}</ref> In 2020, he launched his own beer, "Hucklejack Canadian Lager".<ref name="huckle">{{cite web|url=https://globalnews.ca/news/7097677/dean-brody-interview/|title=Dean Brody on summer anthems and his new beer, Hucklejack Canadian Lager |first=Katie|last=Scott|work=[[Global News]]|date=June 24, 2020|publisher=[[Corus Entertainment]]|access-date=June 24, 2020}}</ref> Brody has run the "Dean Brody Foundation", which supports global initiatives, since the early 2010s.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nhlpa.com/news/1-22352/dean-brody-bowen-byram-team-up-with-nhlpa-goals-dreams|title=DEAN BRODY, BOWEN BYRAM TEAM UP WITH NHLPA GOALS & DREAMS IN FORT STEELE, B.C.|date=July 25, 2022|work=[[National Hockey League Players' Association|NHLPA]]|access-date=September 27, 2022}}</ref>

==Music career==

===2009–2011: ''Dean Brody'' and ''Trail in Life''===
Brody's [[Dean Brody (album)|self-titled debut album]] was released in the United States on April 28, 2009, via the independent label [[Broken Bow Records]]. The album debuted at Number 32 on the U.S. ''Billboard'' [[Top Country Albums]] chart, and was released in Canada on May 12, 2009. "[[Brothers (Dean Brody song)|Brothers]]" peaked at number 26 in the US. "Dirt Road Scholar" and "Undone" were both released in Canada and "Gravity" in the United States.

The first single from Brody's second album, "[[Wildflower (Dean Brody song)|Wildflower]]", was released in April 2010. A second single, "[[Roll That Barrel Out]]", was released in July 2010. The album, ''[[Trail in Life]]'', was released by [[Open Road Recordings]] in August 2010. Other singles included [[Trail in Life (song)|the title track]], "[[People Know You by Your First Name]]" and "[[Little Yellow Blanket]]".

===2012–2014: ''Dirt'' and ''Crop Circles''===
Brody's third studio album, ''[[Dirt (Dean Brody album)|Dirt]]'', was released by Open Road Recordings on April 24, 2012. Its first single, "[[Canadian Girls]]", became Brody's first song to reach the top 40 on the [[Canadian Hot 100]] and his first certified gold digital single. Brody sold out his first headline Dirt Tour across Canada in 2012.

Brody's fourth studio album, ''[[Crop Circles (album)|Crop Circles]]'', was released on November 5, 2013. The lead single, "[[Bounty (song)|Bounty]]", was released on August 19. It was followed by the title track in December 2013, "Another Man's Gold" in April 2014 and "[[Mountain Man (Dean Brody song)|Mountain Man]]" in September 2014.

===2015–2017: ''Gypsy Road'' and ''Beautiful Freakshow''===
Brody's fifth studio album, ''[[Gypsy Road (album)|Gypsy Road]]'', was released on April 21, 2015. The lead single, "Upside Down", was released on February 9. The album's second single, "Bring Down the House", was released to Canadian country radio on May 25, 2015. The album's third single, "[[Love Would Be Enough]]", was released to Canadian country radio on October 23, 2015. The album's fourth single, "Monterey", was released to Canadian country radio in March 2016.

Brody's sixth studio album, ''[[Beautiful Freakshow]]'', was released on October 21, 2016. The album's lead single, "[[Bush Party]]" released to Canadian country radio on 2016,<ref>{{cite web|title=DEAN BRODY LIGHTS UP SUMMER NIGHTS WITH NEW PLAYLIST ESSENTIAL "BUSH PARTY" AVAILABLE JULY 29|url=https://openroadrecordings.com/news/dean-brody-lights-up-summer-nights-with-new-playlist-essential-bush-party-available-july-29/|work=[[Open Road Recordings]]|date=July 28, 2016|access-date=May 22, 2021|archive-date=May 22, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210522020652/https://openroadrecordings.com/news/dean-brody-lights-up-summer-nights-with-new-playlist-essential-bush-party-available-july-29/|url-status=dead}}</ref> and was certified Platinum by [[Music Canada]].<ref name="MC">{{cite certification|region=Canada|artist=Dean Brody|access-date=May 21, 2021}}</ref> The album also included Brody's third number one hit "[[8th Day (song)|8th Day]]",<ref name="Canada Country"/> as well as the Platinum-certified "[[Beautiful Freakshow (song)|Beautiful Freakshow]]" and Gold-certified "[[Time (Dean Brody song)|Time]]".<ref name="MC"/> In 2017, Brody headlined the [[Budweiser Stage]] in [[Toronto, Ontario]] for the first tine.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://topcountry.ca/highlights-dean-brody-tim-hicks-budweiser-stage/|title=What You Missed: Top 5 Moments from Dean Brody & Tim Hicks at Budweiser Stage|date=August 2, 2017|work=Top Country Music {{!}} Country Music News, Charts, Playlists, Videos|access-date=September 12, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref>

===2018–2019: ''Black Sheep''===
On April 26, 2019, Brody released the [[Extended play|EP]] ''[[Black Sheep (EP)|Black Sheep]]'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Dean Brody – Black Sheep|first=Melissa|last=Novacaska|url=http://exclaim.ca/music/article/dean_brody-black_sheep|work=Exclaim.ca|publisher=Ontario Creates|date=April 24, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Five Questions With… Dean Brody|first=Jason|last=Schneider|url=https://www.fyimusicnews.ca/articles/2019/08/23/five-questions-…-dean-brody|work=FYI Music News|date=August 23, 2019}}</ref> which featured four singles, "[[Good Goodbye (Dean Brody song)|Good Goodbye]]", "[[Dose of Country]]", the platinum-certified "[[Whiskey in a Teacup]]",<ref>{{cite web |url=https://topcountry.ca/pick-dean-brody-whiskey-in-a-teacup-2/|title=Top Country Pick: Dean Brody's Whiskey In A Teacup|date=July 4, 2019|work=Top Country|access-date=November 28, 2020}}</ref> and "[[Black Sheep (Dean Brody song)|Black Sheep]]", all of which charted in the top ten of the Canadian Country charts. He co-headlined a tour across Canada with fellow Canadian country artist [[Dallas Smith]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Dean Brody Releases Anticipated EP, Black Sheep, and new single in Advance of Fall Tour – Open Road Recordings |url=https://openroadrecordings.com/news/dean-brody-releases-anticipated-ep-black-sheep-and-new-single-in-advance-of-fall-tour/ |access-date=April 22, 2020 |language=en |archive-date=September 26, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200926115822/https://openroadrecordings.com/news/dean-brody-releases-anticipated-ep-black-sheep-and-new-single-in-advance-of-fall-tour/ |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Dean Brody's New Single, New Album and New Tour|first=Randy|last=Owen|url=https://www.country1011.com/2019/08/21/dean-brodys-new-single-new-album-and-new-tour/|work=101.1 Country|publisher=[[Rogers Media]]|date=August 21, 2019}}</ref>

===2020–present: ''Boys'' and ''Right Round Here''===
In February 2020, Brody independently released the single "[[Can't Help Myself (Dean Brody and The Reklaws song)|Can't Help Myself]]" with [[The Reklaws]] through his own label, Scurvy Dog Music.<ref>{{cite web |title= Dean Brody and The Reklaws on their new single 'Can't Help Myself' |url= https://globalnews.ca/video/6660244/dean-brody-and-the-reklaws-on-their-new-single-cant-help-myself |access-date=June 1, 2020|work=Global News|publisher=Corus Media}}</ref> The song reached No. 1 on the Billboard [[Canada Country]] chart and No. 49 on the [[Canadian Hot 100]].<ref name="BillboardCan">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/dean-brody/chart-history/can/|title=Dean Brody – Canadian Hot 100|magazine=Billboard|access-date=June 23, 2020}}</ref> It was officially the most played song ever at Canadian country radio in a single week on the Nielsen BDS charts with 1782 spins.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.fyimusicnews.ca/articles/2020/06/08/music-news-digest-june-8-2020 |title= Music News Digest, June 8, 2020 |work=FYI Music News|date=June 8, 2020|access-date=June 23, 2020}}</ref> In June 2020, Brody released the single "[[Canadian Summer]]".<ref name="huckle"/> It would become his second consecutive No. 1 at Canadian Country radio, and fifth overall,<ref name="Canada Country">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/dean-brody/chart-history/ccw/|title=Dean Brody – Canada Country|magazine=Billboard|access-date=August 4, 2020}}</ref> while breaking the previous record at Canadian country radio set by "Can't Help Myself" with 1817 spins.<ref name="record">{{cite web|url= https://www.country1043.com/2020/09/25/dean-brody-sitting-at-the-top/|first=Randy|last=Owen|title=Dean Brody: Sitting at the Top|work=104.3 Country|publisher=[[Rogers Media]]|date=September 25, 2020|access-date=November 5, 2020}}</ref>

Brody released his seventh album, ''[[Boys (Dean Brody album)|Boys]]'' on November 18, 2020.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/deanbrody/status/1323308896858132480|title=Dean Brody on Twitter: "BIG NEWS! My new album "Boys" is out Nov 18! As a special sneak peek I'll be playing the full album plus some other songs, with full live production, a day before. I can't wait to see what you think of it!"|via=Twitter|access-date=November 2, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fyimusicnews.ca/articles/2020/11/11/fyi-schedule-upcoming-releases-nov-12-2020|title=FYI Schedule of Upcoming Releases: Nov. 12, 2020|work=FYI Music News|date=November 12, 2020}}</ref> The title track "[[Boys (Dean Brody song)|Boys]]" was released as the third single to country radio off the album and featured American country singer [[Mickey Guyton]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fyimusicnews.ca/articles/2020/11/22/dean-brody-boys|title=Dean Brody: Boys|first=Kerry|last=Doole|date=November 22, 2020|website=FYI Music News}}</ref> The song would also reach #1 on the [[Canada Country]] chart.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mickey Guyton Notches First-Ever No. 1 Song in Canada With Dean Brody Duet 'Boys'|first=Angela|last=Stefano|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/mickey-guyton-dean-brody-boys-no-1-song/|work=Taste of Country|date=March 29, 2021|accessdate=March 31, 2021}}</ref> "[[Lightning Bug (song)|Lightning Bug]]" was released to radio as the fourth single off the album in April 2021.<ref>{{cite web |title=Dean Brody releases another single from his Boys album – "Lightning Bug" |url=https://canadianbeats.ca/2021/05/01/dean-brody-releases-another-single-from-his-boys-album-lightning-bug/|first=Nanci|last=Dagg|website=Canadian Beats Media|date=May 1, 2021}}</ref> Brody then collaborated with fellow Canadian country artist [[Jade Eagleson]] on "[[More Drinkin' Than Fishin']]",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://topcountry.ca/top-country-pick-of-the-week-jade-eagleson-dean-brody-more-drinkin-than-fishin/|title=Pick of the Week – Jade Eagleson & Dean Brody "More Drinkin' Than Fishin'"|date=July 25, 2021|work=Top Country}}</ref> and released "[[I'd Go to Jail]]" as the fifth single from ''Boys''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fyimusicnews.ca/articles/2021/10/13/essentials%E2%80%A6-dean-brody|title=Essentials… with Dean Brody|first=Jason|last=Schneider|work=FYI Music News|date=October 13, 2021}}</ref>

In May 2022, he released the new single "[[Where'd You Learn How to Do That]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://canadianbeats.ca/2022/05/14/dean-brody-prepares-to-make-2022-the-biggest-yet-with-three-great-announcements/|title=Dean Brody prepares to make 2022 the biggest yet with three great announcements|date=May 14, 2022|first=Nanci|last=Dagg|work=Canadian Beats Media|access-date=July 20, 2022}}</ref> The song would go on to become Brody's eight number one in Canada, and he followed it up with the release of "[[You Got the Wrong Guy]]" in October 2022.<ref name="YGTWG"/> In April 2023, he released the single "Broke", which will be included on his ninth studio album, slated for release in the fall of 2023.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://canadianbeats.ca/2023/04/18/dean-brody-releases-new-single-broke/|title=Dean Brody releases new single, "Broke"|date=April 8, 2023|first=Nanci|last=Dagg|work=Canadian Beats Media|access-date=July 12, 2023}}</ref> In July 2023, [[Canadian Country Music Association]] announced that Brody would receive "Gary Slaight Music Humanitarian Award" for his contributions and achievements through his Dean Brody Foundation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cashboxcanada.ca/features-music/dean-brody-be-honoured-ccma-award-achievement-2023-recipient-gary-slaight-music|title=Dean Brody To Be Honoured With CCMA Award Of Achievement As The 2023 Recipient Of The Gary Slaight Music Humanitarian Award|date=July 7, 2023|access-date=July 12, 2023|work=Cashbox Canada}}</ref>

In September 2023, Brody released his eighth album ''[[Right Round Here]]'', which includes his previous singles from 2022 and 2023.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://canadianbeats.ca/2023/09/01/dean-brodys-eighth-studio-album-right-round-here-to-drop-on-september-15|title=Dean Brody's Eighth Studio Album, Right Round Here, to Drop on September 15|first=Nanci|last=Dagg|date=September 1, 2023|work=Canadian Beats Media|access-date=September 13, 2023}}</ref> He embarked on the acoustic "Right Round Here" Tour across Canada to support the album in the fall of 2023.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://canadianbeats.ca/2023/05/30/dean-brody-announces-right-round-here-acoustic-tour-this-fall-and-new-album-by-the-same-name/|title=Dean Brody Announces Right Round Here Acoustic Tour this Fall and New Album by the Same Name|date=May 30, 2023|work=Canadian Beats Media|first=Nanci|last=Dagg|access-date=August 26, 2023}}</ref> In 2024, Brody released the single "Your Mama Would Hate Me" with the [[James Barker Band]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://completecountry.ca/dean-brody-drops-new-single-your-mama-would-hate-me-ft-james-barker-band/|title=DEAN BRODY Drops New Single “Your Mama Would Hate Me” Ft. James Barker Band|date=April 5, 2024|access-date=September 11, 2024|work=Complete Country}}</ref>
